title: Erdős Problem #1120: Shortest Path in Polynomial Sublevel Sets
description: For monic f of degree n with roots in the unit disk, what is the shortest path in {|f(z)| ≤ 1} from 0 to |z| = 1? Conjectured → ∞ with n. Halász 4.22. Open.

sections.title: Main Problem
sections.summary: Worst-case path length → ∞ with degree n.

sections.title: Known Results
sections.summary: Trivial bound 1, Clunie–Netanyahu existence, slow growth conjecture.

overview.historicalContext: This is Problem 4.22 from Halász's collection, attributed to Erdős. Clunie and Netanyahu showed that a path in E from 0 to the unit circle always exists. The question is how long it must be.
overview.problemStatement: For a monic polynomial f of degree n with roots in the closed unit disk, what is the shortest path in E = {|f(z)| ≤ 1} from z = 0 to |z| = 1?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the unit-rooted polynomial, the sublevel set, and the shortest path length. The main conjecture (divergence with n) and known results are stated as axioms.
keyInsights: For f(z) = z^n, E is the unit disk and path length is 1
Clunie–Netanyahu proved such a path always exists
Erdős conjectured the worst-case path length → ∞ but slowly
E is a lemniscate; root clustering creates thin passages
Connected to Problem #1041 on polynomial sublevel set covering

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #1120 asks for the shortest path in a polynomial sublevel set from the origin to the unit circle. The path length is at least 1 (achieved by z^n), but whether it grows to ∞ with the degree remains open.
conclusion.implications: A resolution would illuminate the geometry of polynomial lemniscates and the topology of sublevel sets in complex analysis.
openQuestions: Does the worst-case path length tend to infinity with n?
Which root configurations produce the longest shortest paths?
Is the path length bounded by a polynomial in n?
